title: Playing a legitimate support is harder than I gave it credit for
body:
Hey everyone.

So yesterday I was playing on my alternative account for a while when I got slapped with autofill. Normally I play mage supports and do the typical sightstone -> full AP as a Brand main. However I ran into the issue of only having 2 supports on this account: Nami and Braum.

I locked Nami and quickly looked into the builds I should be running before the game started. I was actually surprised. I'm obviously not good at league so when I reached mid game with 5 active items to manage and the sole responsibility for protecting my adc, I found it difficult. Eventually we won the game and I managed a 3/4/29 game.

The thing is that I've always built damage items and relied only on my skills and focused on the enemy team. Changing the view into peeling and supporting was alot more challenging than I thought it would be. The gameplay was interactive and it felt rewarding.

It's mechanically easier, and I would never argue that.

But it requires REALLY good attention to the game, and the best supports do a good job of knowing what to ward, when to ward it, paying attention to minimap and pinging other players. The best supports understand that since they don't have to cs, they should be responsible for a good chunk of the macro-game.

Doing that is not easy. If all you do is stand in lane and heal the adc when they get poked, then yeah, that's easy. But that's being an awful support, too, so I'm not sure how much that counts.

This and you also learn when to pick fights as support since it can set up a kill for the adc.
A good support tends to be the play maker or play saver in the healers case for the team and most do not realize that

You nailed it.

Not having to cs makes Support an easier role, generally. I'm not saying there aren't supports that have hard mechanics; I'm saying that the average difficulty level of playing support is lower than the average difficulty of playing other roles, specifcally because they don't have to cs.

I don't think there's a strong counter-argument to that.
You have to manage active items more in teamfights, including warding as enemies duck in an out of vision. Probably isn't more mechanically intensive than cs but the two skills aren't exactly 1:1.

Yeah, that's the most difficult thing about support, to be sure. In my experience though, that has not been as difficult to get used to (and do decently) as csing while dealing with the opponents poke and what-not. 

There's still plenty of mechanical skill difference between a bad and a good support; it's not as though there isn't anything mechanical about playing support, but I think the solo laners have more mechanical demand. *shrug*  That's just been my consistent experience.

As a sort of sidenote, I think conceding that point makes it easier to convince people that supports DO have difficult jobs besides mechanical intensity. Part of the reason I'm eager to give up that point is because it transitions into discussing the support's role in the macro-strategy of the game. I wish more supports would understand that (and work on it), and I wish more solo laners would be willing to listen to the support's shot-calling. Again, I think a good support can watch the map much more easily than anyone else (except maybe the jungler).
I'm not sure it's mechanically easier. The champs themselves often are, but the role…

That's exactly why I say it. The champs are not MORE difficult, mechanically, than other champs. Plus they don't have to cs. On average, that makes them mechanically easier to play. 

I don't mean that as a diss to support players; check my history and you'll see it's quite the opposite. But as someone who DOES play a lot of support and mid (and some adc), I can confidently say that the support role does not require the same level of mechanics as other roles, on average.

You should never recommend support as a position to start in League, to be honest

It is a lane where you can focus on honing your basic skills at first on a 1vs1 island, and as you start to make progress you start looking at the map and understand how to play it in its entirety to then be able to transition to wither jungle (if he want to control the map) or a carry role (if he want to be always in the middle of thr action/fight) or support if he can't really hold up mecanically

No, the reason support is so good to start out in is because you don't farm. By removing that entire aspect of the game you allow the person to focus only on interacting with your ADC, your enemy laners and watching the map. As someone mentioned in a thread the other day, one of the biggest things holding people back in lower ranks is not farming well. 

Further, since you're there for the team through your utility it means that getting behind is less frustrating since you can still do something even when behind. Farming is important to learn but it is not something you want to bog down a new player with since it could easily turn them away. If you introduce the more kinetic aspects of the game to them first and they decide they like that then they can move on from there.

This does not mean that there is not a lot to learn to become a truly great support, far from it, but it is the safest position to have a newbie try out.

I usually try to keep 3 items with active effects max unless I see the real need to build more.

My main issue is that I'm not used to move my fingers quickly to them numbers and I can mess things up really easily.

As a support main for approximately 4 seasons now, I would like to agree with you, but I feel compelled to point out that it's less "more difficult" and more "different". Having mained support, and specifically Thresh since his release, I find it very impressive when people can play other roles well. The positioning involved in Carry roles, the knowledge of when and how to gank in the Jungle, knowing when to group and when to split as Top, etc. Support is a rather different role than most others, it's true, but IMO, that's all it is: a different playstyle, not necessarily a harder one.
